titleStmt.title: The Richard Coer de Lyon Multitext

editionStmt.edition: The Richard Coer de Lyon Multitext: Wynken de Worde 1509

respStmt.resp: Transcribed from the digital images and encoded by
respStmt.name: Caitlin Postal
Barkley M. Ramsey
Sarah N. Moore
respStmt.note: Collaborative edition transcribed and encoded with introduction by Sarah Moore, Caitlin Postal, and Barkley Ramsey.

origin.p: Printed in x in or around 1509 by Wynken de Worde.

figure.figDesc: Woodcut Illustration. Image takes up approximately three-quarters of the page. Knight in foreground, probably King Richard, on a horse holding a sword upright. Foregrounded knight is wearing armor and a hat with large feathers, horse also has armor and feathers on head. Knight in background is in full armor with helmet and is resting a lance in their shoulder. There is various vegetation on the ground. Image bordered by two solid lines, the outer line twice the thickness of the inner.

body.l: Orde kynge of glorye
body.note: Missing the decorative initial for the uppercase [L] in [Lord]; there is a blank area on the page about 8-10 characters wide and five lines tall.
body.l: Suche grace and suche vyctory
Thou sendest to kynge Rycharde
That neuer was founde cowarde
It is good to here Iestes
Of his prowesse and his conquestes
Many romayns men make newe
Of good knyghtes and of trewe
Of theyr dedes men rede romauns
Bothe in Englonde and in Fraunce
Of Rowlande and of Olyuere
body.note: The Prologue includes reference to other romances of the Middle Ages including, in the lines that follow, Roland and Oliver (l. 11; Song of Roland), Alexander the Great (l. 13), Charlemagne (l. 13), King Arthur (l. 14), Sir Gawain (l. 14), Archbishop Turpin (l. 16), Ogier the Dane (l. 16), Hector and Achilles ("troye men" in ll. 17-19). The narrator here refers to the French "rymes" (l. 21) that were not known in England because "lewde man can frensshe none / of an hondred vnneth one" (l. 23-24), or roughly "lewed/unlearned men can [read] in French none of a hundred difficult ones." This sets the stage for telling new gestes or romances in the English vernacular.
body.l: And of euery desepere
Of Alysaunder and of Charlemayne
Of kynge Arthur and of Gawayne
How they were knyghtes good and curtoys
Of Turpyn and of Oger the danoys
Of troye men rede in ryme
What was by olde tyme
Of Hector and of Achylles
What folke they slewe in prees
In fraunce these rymes were wrought
Euery englysshe ne knewe it nought
Lewde man can frensshe none
Of an hondred vnneth one
Neuertheles with gladde chere
Yf that ye wyll now here
Newe Iestes I vnderstonde
Of doughty knyghtes of Englonde
Therefore now I wyll you rede
Of a kynge doughty of dede
Kynge Rycharde was the beste
That is founde in ony Ieste
Now all that here this talkynge
God gyue them good endynge
body.fw:
¶ Here begynneth the hystorye of Kynge Ry:
charde cure du lyon / and fyrst of his byrth.
body.l: LOrdes harken now beforne
body.note: The L in "Lord" is a decorative initial about eight characters wide and five lines tall. The initial has the image of a bearded man's face on its left side looking leftward and a bird-like creature on its right side looking upwards. Above the bird is a partial flower or sun.
body.l: How kynge Rycharde was borne
His fader was cleped kynge Harry
In his tyme sykerly
As I fynde in this sawe
Saynt Thomas was Islawe
body.note: Thomas Becket, canonized as Saint Thomas in 1173 BCE, became King Henry II's chancellor in 1155 and archbishop of Canterbury in 1162. Thomas' relationship with Henry II deteriorated with disputes over ecclesiastical and monarchical jurisdiction (Larkin, n. 40). Thomas was murdered in 1170 before his altar in Canterbury, which is referenced in the following line of the poem.
body.l: At Caunterbury before the auter stone
There myracles be done many one
Whan he was .xx. wynter olde
He was a kynge swythe bolde
He wolde no wyfe I vnderstonde
With grete tresour thoughe they her fonde
Neuertheles his barons hym redde
That he graunted them a wyfe to wedde
Hastely he sente his sonde
In to many a dyuers londe
The fayrest woman that was on lyue
They sholde brynge hym to wyue
Messengers be redy dyght
To shyppe they wente that same nyght
And theyr sayle vp they drowe
The wynde them serued well I nowe
And they came amyddes the see
No wyndes brethe ne had he
body.note: Footer likely used as a navigational tool in the printing process. Footer contains a cross pattee, a symbol that has been appropriated by white supremacists since at least the 1930s, when Nazis rose to power. The cross pattee has been harnessed to promote violence, Islamophobia, anti-Semitism, homophobia, transphobia, ableism, and misogyny, and we have chosen in this digital edition to not replicate the symbol and rather render it as a plus sign. For more information on the symbol, please see and this piece from the Washington Post: . The footer also contains pagination that consists of a capital letter and roman numerals i–iiii. This occurs on every other page. After two sets, ten pages are skipped before the next iteration. This continues in the manuscript for letters A-Q.
